report_title: Electric Transmission Line & Tower Installation in the US
executive_summary: Electric transmission lines and tower installation have continued to grow through the end of 2024 as the electricity needs continue. Contractors thrived even amid the pandemic as constructing and maintaining electrical power lines are vital to every sector of the economy. The need for power continued as the economy recovered and the manufacturing sector resumed operations. Companies continue to receive new projects as the shift toward renewable energy has led to the need for more transmission lines. Revenue has expanded at a CAGR of 1.2% to $56.8 billion through 2024, including a 1.1% dip in 2024 alone. Even so, with the competitive nature of industry operations, profit has remained at a standstill as companies continue to place lower bids to secure long-term contracts.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Renewable Energy Continues to Make Its Mark
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The ongoing shift toward renewable energy has spurred increased construction, mainly as many renewable energy sources are located in remote areas that require new transmission lines to reach consumers. Government incentives, like tax credits, have spurred businesses and homeowners to embrace renewable energy, boosting the need for lines and towers. This trend has been further reinforced by the recent Inflation Reduction Act, which provides production and investment tax credits based on the type of energy source and specific projects.

While there is a need for new construction and existing repairs, profitability is limited. Companies bid for competitive prices to receive new contracts from clients. Most companies operate in a local market, so concentration remains low and consolidation activity is minimal. Some larger companies may expand their footprint and cover a larger base, but they typically avoid areas that are too far away because doing so will raise transportation costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The New Technology Provides a Boost
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Worker safety has become a prevalent issue. Companies are using drones to inspect towers and transmission lines instead of asking employees to scale dangerous heights. Automated systems and robots can help string cables or perform high-voltage inspections, which poses a risk. Smart grid technology helps transmit electricity more efficiently while reducing carbon emissions. It also helps restore energy more quickly after a power outage. High-voltage transmission lines allow companies to transport electricity over long distances.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Approval Process Can Take Some Time
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Building new transmission lines and towers requires approval from multiple parties, which can often hold up construction. Companies must get approval from government agencies, landowners and utility companies. Since construction can have significant environmental impacts, assessments and mitigation measures are often required, which can delay projects. Different bodies may clash over projects if they do not meet their particular interests. Environmental groups may push for transmission lines for renewable energy since they are greener, while businesses may choose to prioritize profitable projects.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Construction Continues at a Slower Pace
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While the construction of new towers and transmission lines is still underway, there is limited space for new construction. Even so, the shift toward renewable energies will generate growth for companies. Upgrading existing infrastructure to accommodate decentralized, renewable energy generation will also be crucial. Offshore wind projects, in particular, will look to play a significant role. It takes sophisticated towers and transmission lines to help transmit offshore wind to an onshore electric grid.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Funding Keeps the Industry Moving
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The recently passed Bipartisan Infrastructure Law will provide $10.5 billion in funding for grid resilience and $2.5 billion in transmission facilitation. This will accelerate alterations and repairs on the current transmission infrastructure since most transmission lines are aging. Funding for green projects will be more readily available for companies seeking loan approval. Renewable portfolio standards will mandate states to generate a specific portion of electricity through clean energy, bolstering the need for new installation lines.

Internal competition will remain high throughout the outlook period. Regional variations will prompt companies to broaden their market reach to stay competitive, ensuring no area remains untapped. Even so, new installation companies will enter the industry to try and establish themselves in these areas. Contractors will engage in significant price competition as they vie for project acquisitions, making it a buyer's market. Installers will need to find ways to offer the best value to win contracts, putting pressure on profit but ultimately keeping it steady throughout the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Transmission Technology Advancements Are Still on the Horizon
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Grid-enhancing technologies (GETs), which include dynamic line rating, power-flow control devices and data analytical tools, may benefit installers in the future. Some companies may choose to implement them into existing transmission lines. While these technologies will help bolster electricity transmission, delays may occur as some regulators and utility companies may not see these technologies as profitable. Despite these challenges, the long-term benefits of improved grid reliability, increased capacity and optimized energy distribution make GETs a promising avenue for modernization.

industry_definition: This industry constructs transmission lines and towers for electricity distribution, with firms specifically engaging in new work, additions and alterations.
key_trends: Market share concentration remains low. There are a significant number of small-sized subcontractors that fulfill demand in more local markets throughout the United States.
Small companies still have room to compete. Regional differences provide an incentive for existing companies to expand their operating market.
The recently passed Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act continues to bolster revenue for contractors. The bill provides funding for new transmission lines and upgrades for existing ones.

With the recent push toward renewable energy, contractors have found a new avenue for projects. With new renewable plants being constructed, the owners require the installation of transmission lines and towers to help bring that electricity to consumers and businesses.

Quanta Services' acquisition of Cupertino Electronics for $1.5 billion enhances its service offerings in low-voltage electrical solutions and renewable energy. This strategic move positions Quanta to meet the swelling need for energy infrastructure.

Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors are becoming more significant. This has caused a surge in projects for electric transmission line and tower installation companies from renewable energy utility providers.
The recently passed Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act will provide funding to improve and modernize the country's infrastructure. This includes new line construction, upgrades, and repairs.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market considers the electricity generated from natural gas, coal and petroleum and their need for electrical transmission line and tower installation. The need for fossil fuels is dwindling as the entire globe is shifting to renewable energy.

This market considers the electricity created through nuclear fission, and their demand for electrical transmission line and tower installation. Popular opinion on nuclear power plants is divided, and this division is likely to continue moving forward. Despite the controversy surrounding nuclear energy, it's a significant source of the nation's energy.

This market considers the electricity generated from wind, hydropower, solar and biomass and their demand for electrical transmission line and tower installation. While still out shadowed by fossil fuels, electricity generated from renewable energy has increased gradually in the last 10 years. The global effort to reduce carbon emission and promote sustainable economies will increase this market segment moving forward.

products_and_services.product_description: Electric transmission line and tower installation companies create comprehensive network solutions, including the construction of new towers in underserved or untapped markets.
Tower installation firms are contractually required to maintain their towers and repair any necessary structural damage. These contractual obligations keep revenue from maintenance services stable.

Installation companies also provide additions to their towers, any necessary alterations and emergency reconstruction services. In the shift toward renewable energy, tower additions and alterations have taken a back seat to new constructions.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast's population and economic activity are widely dispersed, so electrical networks cover a wide area. The concentration of activity in the Southeast reflects the infrastructure required to connect the large geographically dispersed population settlements across the region, relative to the more concentrated Mid-Atlantic and West regions.
The Southwest's disparate population requires longer power transmission networks. Texas holds more industry establishments than any other state.

The West region has a high level of electric transmission line and tower installation companies to meet demand from California in particular. California is home to numerous tech companies, boosting the need for sufficient transmission infrastructure. California also holds a greater population than any other state, driving demand for electric transmission line and tower installation companies.

regulations_points.regulation_title: PROPER ADHERENCE TO REGULATIONS IS REQUIRED
regulations_points.regulation_description: For its employees, installers must comply with licensing, permitting and inspection requirements that apply to contractors, electricians and engineers.
The Energy Policy Act of 2005 provided tax incentives and loan guarantees energy producers, including provisions for renewable energy and energy efficiency projects.

FERC oversees the regulation of electricity transmission and wholesale sales across state lines. Electric transmission line and tower installers must comply with FERC's mandates to ensure safe and reliable grid operation.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE NORTH AMERICAN ELECTRIC RELIABILITY CORPORATION (NERC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: NERC coordinates the interconnected power systems nationwide, ensuring reliability and efficiency. Each regional power grid is linked to one of its three major systems.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Market Share Concentration is Slightly Elevated
concentration_points.concentration_description: The electric transmission line and tower installation industry comprises various large and small companies that cater to different project scales and geographic regions.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small Companies Still Have Room to Compete
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most smaller companies need to build reputations for specialized types of construction (e.g. transmission line erection or cable laying), focusing on a local market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the highest expenses for installers, accounting for a third of revenue. These items include steel, plastic, metal pipes, wires, safety equipment and heavy-duty tools.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Subcontracting also represents a significant portion of total purchase costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A large share of the work installers receive contracts for is subcontracted to other construction companies and is accounted for as a purchase cost given the temporary but direct relation to a project's cost.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Remains Steady Despite Economic Shakeups
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit only accounts for a modest portion of revenue. Even so, profit never falls too low or gets too high because companies engage in competitive bidding to lower costs and win over clients.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled Labor Is Integral to Success
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are expected to account for nearly a quarter of revenue and have remained relatively steady. Costs categorized within this segment include traditional hourly rates, salaries and worker benefits but exclude subcontracting costs, which are considered part of purchases.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Electric transmission line and tower installation is considerably more dependent on labor than it is capital. Companies can reduce capital costs by renting machinery, but this has very little influence over average wages.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Shift to Renewable Energy Bolsters Construction
volatility_points.volatility_description: Environmental concerns prompt consumers and businesses to switch to renewable energy. This transition drives the construction of additional transmission lines and towers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Government Investment Continues to Play a Role
volatility_points.volatility_description: Government investment in transmission lines and infrastructure is set to benefit from the recently passed Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: New smart grid technology allows electricity generators and service providers to easily share information to ensure operations are running smoothly.

FAQs.question: Does your company work to anticipate changes in sales based on current market performance?
FAQs.answer: Companies that enter into long-term maintenance contracts will exhibit more stable revenue, even during periods of volatile end-market performance.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a diversified client base, or are sales heavily dependent on one market?
FAQs.answer: Electrical power transmission lines and tower installers serve a variety of markets, including fossil fuel, nuclear and renewable energy sources. Companies can diversify their markets to hedge against volatility.

FAQs.question: Have the rising prices of key construction inputs significantly affected profit margins in recent years?
FAQs.answer: As key input prices spike, it can negatively impact average profitability as companies are forced to absorb these price hikes. Companies can enter fixed-rate contracts with suppliers to hedge against price swings.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Firms near key selling markets will exhibit lower transportation costs and higher profitability. Firms near key input suppliers will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company adopted drone technology?
FAQs.answer: Drones can be used to map job sites, investigate transmission lines and reduce overall labor requirements.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via automation?
FAQs.answer: Labor costs can be reduced by adopting automated technology such as materials tracking software as well as others such as drones. Labor costs can further be reduced through subcontracted labor in conjunction with the latest technologies.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have not significantly impacted company profit margin recently.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: Companies tend to follow federal and state guidelines to make sure health and safety requirements are met.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: One of the biggest financing challenges for companies is purchase costs. Purchase costs can be volatile so companies may enter into long-term contracts to hedge against this.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit never falls too low or gets too high because companies engage in competitive bidding to lower costs and win over clients.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Technological advancements change rapidly in this industry and participants must integrate new technologies effectively to gain an advantage over competitors.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers? How effective is your company at competing on tender?
FAQs.answer: Contracts are often open to bidding and industry participants must be able to provide competitive tender while remaining profitable.

FAQs.question: How much of your company's performance is reliant on electric power consumption? How do you prepare for variation in the intake of electric power?
FAQs.answer: Electricity demand is driven by households, manufacturers and industrial producers. Increased demand from these markets drives electricity consumption; companies will ultimately benefit, as the entire economy is hinged upon proper and consistent power delivery.

FAQs.question: What proportion of the projects that you service are funded by the government?
FAQs.answer: Local and state governments provide some grants for transmission line construction and upgrades. Higher levels of government investments can stimulate revenue growth for contractors.
